billEvents.eventText: REFERRED TO INVESTIGATIONS AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

title: Authorizes operation of toll-free hotline to relay information concerning the failure to collect sales and compensating use taxes
summary: Authorizes the commissioner of taxation and finance to operate a toll free twenty-four hour hotline for the public to use to report information concerning the failure of any person to collect the tax on retail sales and the compensating use tax; provides that if such report results in the collection of any taxes or fines, the informant shall receive ten percent of such taxes and fines.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2317

TITLE OF BILL:
An act to amend the tax law, in relation to authorizing the operation of
a toll-free hotline for the public to use to relay information concern-
ing the failure to collect sales and compensating use taxes

PURPOSE OR GENERAL IDEA OF BILL:
This legislation directs the Commissioner of Taxation and Finance to
establish a hot line number for consumers to call and report a case of
sales tax evasion or sales tax fraud on the part of a merchant. If the
Consumer's report leads to a subsequent investigation and a fine is
levied by the Department of Taxation and Finance, the consumer is to
receive an award equal to 10% of the fine levied and the taxes
collected.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
This bill amends section 1817 of the Tax Law by adding a new subdivision
to require the Commissioner of Taxation and Finance to establish and
operate a toll-free hot line for the public to use to relay information
concerning the failure of any person to collect sales tax. To ensure the
confidentiality of the person reporting the infraction, a case number
will be assigned to each report and communication shall be referenced
solely according to such case number. The Commissioner shall pay rewards
of ten percent of the tax collected and the fine levied as a result of
the report.

JUSTIFICATION:
According to recent figures, New York State could lose in excess of $600
million dollars a year as a result of sales tax evasion. Merchants who
fail to collect the appropriate sales tax harm both the state's tax
coffers and their competitors in the market.  This bill will give a
monetary incentive to consumers to report a sales tax violation that
they have witnessed or experienced. The confidentiality of the person
reporting the infraction is ensured through the assignment of a case
number.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
Minimal.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the one hundred twentieth day after it
shall have become a law except that any rules or regulations necessary
for the timely implementation of this act on its effective date may be
promulgated before such date.
